results.notes:
LIKELY SPECIES NAME: Entoloma cf. holmvassdalenense, see reference below:

NOTE: Identification is based on an article published in 29 DEC 2014, entitled: “One new and one rare species of Entoloma from the Norwegian nature reserve Holmvassdalen”, Authored By: Øyvind Weholt, Jostein Lorås, and Siw Elin Eidissen of Nesna University College N-8700 Nesna, Norway MO#: 375540 iNat #: MO#: 375540 iNat #: 29519580

NOTE: A specimen will soon be sent for DNA testing

NEARBY FLORA: Conifer: Douglas Fir, Hemlock, Cedar; Deciduous: Big-leaf Maple, Red Huckleberry; Evergreen: Black/Purple Huckleberry, Licorice Fern, Sword Fern.

SUBSTRATE: Leaf Litter, Dense Humus Soil, Well-decayed Conifer Wood, Needle Duff, Moss.

HABIT: Several (i.e., 8-10 within 1-foot area), Clustered near a Decayed Conifer Branch.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Shade to Partial Shade

ODOR: Pleasant Mushroom

TASTE: Unknown.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: 2–17 mm across, hemispherical to plano-convex, with a weakly depressed centre or not (i.e., very small and young specimens), straightened, yet somewhat incurved, irregular margin, distinctly and coarsely squamulose all over. The color is dependent on light intensity: In Natural Light, the cap appears a Greyish-Brown, whereas indoors the Cap is intensely Black. The Cap Surface has blackish to dark brown squamules, elsewhere pale to dark brown. The Margin is not Striated. There is no bruising nor color change when cut.

GILLS: White, adnexed/emarginate, close, at places crowded. There is no bruising nor color change when cut.

STIPE: 1 – 4.3cm long, depending on specimen age. Width varies…narrow at the Apex (~ 2mm) and slightly fusiform at the base (~ 3-4mm). Color is White near the base, but becoming Grey, with the apex being darkest. Clavate, near-central attachment. The surface is smooth w/very fine fibrils, ~1.5” long. There is no bruising nor color change when cut.

SPORES: Light Brown

MYCELIA: White, directly below the forest duff. Appears to run shallow in the packed substrate, ~ 5mm.

results.notes:
Three fruibodies growing in short grass near mature oaks. Stipe base extraction failed due to being waterlogged/rotten, but from what I could see the volval sack was small and delicate.
The largest cap was 4.5 cm wide. The spores appear to be subglobose and under 10 microns at x400 with no mounting agent.
DNA Results and Discussion (revised on 28-Jul-22):
A clean full-length consensus nrITS sequence of 488 bps was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The ITS1 and ITS2 regions in this species are 172 and 156 bps long, while the highly conserved 5.8S region is of the standard length of 160 bps. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
A BLASTn of this sequence returned a single 100% match with https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/MH939272, which is the first record of this taxon published in GenBank. For more information, see http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20sp-N68. Phylogeneitcally, this species is as sister taxon of Amanita “sp-S14”. The present ITS sequence is 98.2-99.0% similar to accession of “sp-S14”.
results.location_name: Somerset Co., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
A light-brown capped grisette with a striate-tuberculate margin. The cap is 5.3 cm wide, and the overall fruitbody height is 9.3 cm. The stipe surface is rather featureless. The volval sack appears to be missing/friable, and the only visible part of it is a grayish “flange” (see pick). The spores appear perfectly globose and generally 9-11 microns wide (at x400 with no mounting agent).
The young fb seen in the last pic was not collected.

DNA Results & Discussion (posted 5-Apr-20; edited 28-May-22):
A clean and contiguous nrITS sequence was obtained from this material by Dr. Kudzma and posted to this observation. It’s a joined contig because of a single point of heterogeneity at a poly-AC-repeat in the ITS1 sublocus, as seen in the forward and reverse reads; one haplotype-1 has ACACACACACAC and the other one adds one more AC. There are no ambiguities in the legible regions of the reads.
A BLASTn of the full-length ITS sequence returned 40+ hits with 98.1~100% similarity to accessions of Amanita texasorora, most of which had been submitted to GenBank by Dr. Rod Tulloss.

results.notes:
This is what I would call a “substantial Russula”, worthy to be worked on and maybe even sequenced. It’s robust, hefty, thick-fleshed and quite attractive (by Russula standards). It’s been a while since I paid attention to this large genus, so when I came across this critter, I couldn’t just walk away. :-)
A group of 6-7 fruitbodies growing in a gravel patch along the path under a large oak, with beech, maple and a single birch nearby. The red color (between oac607 and oac614) was absolutely gorgeous when fresh, but faded post collection, especially at the margins where it became pinkish-yellow. The cap surface was covered in a whitish felted bloom in all basidiomata. The cap cuticle hardly peeled at the margin, which only became short-striate after desiccation. The largest cap was 10 cm wide. The gills were cream-colored, bruising brownish, forking at stipe or 2-5 mm away from it. The spore print is white to palest cream. The white stipe bruised brownish and was 4.5 cm long max, 3 cm wide at the flaring apex and uniformly 2-2.2 cm wide below. The flesh was white, firm, unchanging. Odor nil to slightly fruity (?). Taste was readily bitter.
Overall this fits flavisiccans well, except that the cap color here is scarlet/blood red rather than rose red (cf. obs 171059).
Basic Microscopy:
Spores were mounted in Melzer’s, visualized at x1000, and measured in profile (=dorsi-ventral) or face (=dorsal/ventral) views.
[20/1/1]: L x W = 7.0~8.4 (-8.6) x 6.5~7.4 (-7.7) μm, L’ x W’ = 7.6 × 7.0μm; Q = 1.03~1.20(-1.21), Q’ = 1.10.
Amyloid, thin walled, globose (3 spores) to sublobose (12 spores) to lower-range broadly ellipsoid (4 spores). Warts amyloid, not exceeding 0.5 μm in height and generally 0.3 μm tall. Connectors forming a partial to almost complete reticulum.
G.F. Bills gives the following spore data for R. flavisiccans from the type collection:
“Basidiospores yellowish white to pale yellow with pinkish tint (Romagnesi Ib, IIa) in mass; 7-8.5(-9) x 6.5-8(-8.5) μm, globose, subglobose to broadly obovate; ornamentation amyloid, relatively low, mostly 0.2-0.5 μm high, occasionally up to 1 μm high, consisting of interconnecting fine lines and thin ridges with blunt to conical verrucae, or verrucae aligned in short chains forming a complete to nearly complete, usually dense reticulum…”.
My observations are in good agreement with the above microscopic details.
DNA Sequencing Discussion & Results (posted on 12-Jun-20; revised on 28-Jul-22):
> A clean and contiguous full-length nrITS (ITS1-5.8S-ITS2) consensus sequence of 603 bps has been obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma from two clean reads. The three subloci are 191, 160 and 252 bps long, respectively. There are two ambiguities – one “Y” in ITS1 and one “Y” in ITS2.
> A BLASTn of this sequence returned a hit list with 12 top russula accessions being 99.4-99.8% similar to it (72-100% query cover). However, only one of these, EU589162, mentions a real species epithet (‘cf. flavisiccans’). Steve Russell gave this species his own cryptic code, “sp-IN13” (7 accessions, 99.5-99.8% similar), though his collections on MycoMap feature russulas with cap colors mostly ranging from bleached out color to rich yellow; only one collection had red caps similar to mine.
> MUSCLE alignment of the 6 full-length GenBank ITS accessions with that of MO375607 is shown in Fig. 1. The sequences differ at 5 isolated positions, of which 3 appear to be fully polymorphic sites [i.e., C/T/Y/N, C/T/N and A/G/N, where “N” stands for any base but is likely to be either “Y” or “R” (no manual edits?)] and the remaining 2 still feature ambiguities. This voucher sampling likely represents the extent of nrITS intraspecific variation in what appears to be a single species.
> The painted picture suggests that the accessions likely represent the same taxon, presumably R. flavisiccans, though a species group cannot be ruled out completely in this rather large genus, like it is the case with Cortinarius and Agaricus. R. flavisiccans appears to be widespread in eastern North America – the unsequenced G.F. Bill’s holotype came from Virginia, while the 6 GenBank accessions hailed from Florida, Indiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi and Tennessee.

results.notes:
On the ground and near the bases of trees in coniferous grove, Norway spruce, pine.
Spore morphology differs when spores are mounted in cotton blue vs. Congo red.
Cotton Blue (photos labeled CB): Apical projections absorb the liquid and decompose. One photo shows this very well. Another photo shows spores without the projections, which apparently had dissolved. Without the projections the spores appear to be ellipsoid, 26-30 × 9-11. Surface of spores finely verrucose, best seen with the cotton blue mount (but not pictured, as photos taken through my better scope (binocular) fail to show subtle detail.) Contents of spores not seen in cotton blue mount.
Congo red (photos labeled CR): Apical projections seen, the addition of which forms a fusoid shape, 32-38 × 9-11 including the projections. Contents best seen under Congo red, two large guttules as well as smaller ones.

results.notes:
Perhaps because the disc is so dark, the photos overstate the paleness of the margin. Photo #6 is the best representation of cap color. Margin grayish but paler within the grooves. Photo #9 emphasizes brown more than gray, but true color favors gray over brown.
Marginal striations occupying over 50% of the cap radius, grooves deep/prominent. Raised lines strongly tuberculate.
Stipe apex with tiny white floccose scales.
Gills notched/attached, seceding.
Basal volva a thick persistent membrane, mostly buried. Photos #2, #3 show fruit body after it was popped out of the ground.
Short gills raggedly truncate.
Context soft (the stipe broke away from the base). I looked for a limbus internus, but found no obvious/prominent such presence. In photo #11 a small basal flap appears as a possibility for a limbus internus.
Odor none; taste mild to very slightly sour.
Spores mainly globose with little deviation from Q=1.0; 10<D<12.
Within 10 feet of where obs 248445 was found. Mossy mowed pathway with oak and white pine.

results.notes: Question: I seem to be finding a lot of these cone-like pods (C?) pushing up from the forest floor in the vicinity of Russula mushrooms (A) and (B) Indian Pipes (Monotropa uniflora). I know A and B have symbiotic interrelationships with some trees but is there any known relationship with these pods? Could be just a coincidence but in any case I’d be interested to know what others think and if anyone knows what these pods are. I’ve spent a lot of time in the woods but have never come across them.

results.notes:
Collected by Michael McKnight. Growing among moss and leaf litter near Quercus alba, Carya ovata and possibly other hardwoods. Locally common. Context unchanging. Pores with scattered reddish spots and bruising very weakly blue on 1 fruiting body. Otherwise, pores not bruising. Reticulation yellow to red. Taste mild. All structures inamyloid. results.notes: Solitary basidiome fruiting from a well-decayed hardwood stump, within mixed woods (very mature trees – mostly pine, oak, hickory and sweetgum). Macro: Fruiting body relatively small and dainty (somewhat fragile), appearing to be slightly over matured and on its way to the mushroom heavens; Pileus approximately 2.5 cm broad, convex to campanulate with a relatively prominent, and somewhat acute, umbo (possibly in age?), strongly lined with striations from just below the disc to margin, finely tomentose to granulose (more dense towards disc), somewhat appressed-fibrillose at disc, a darker cocoa(ish) brown at disc and a mocha-cream color elsewhere and fading towards margin; Lamellae very crowded, pinkish-salmon in color, concolorous throughout, becoming flexuous upon drying/aging; Stipe about 4.5 cm long and 2-3 mm thick, fragile, slightly eccentric, off-white to pale yellowish, gradually tapering from base to apex, basal mycelium white; Odor/Taste odor non-distinctive, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores subglobose to broadly ovoid, hyaline in water, hyaline to pale yellowish in NH4OH/KOH, thin to slightly thick-walled, frequently monoguttulate, ~ 6.0 – 8.0 (8.1 – 8.8) x (5.0 – 5.4) 5.5 – 6.4 (6.5 – 7.0) μm; Q = 1.07 – 1.37; N = 58; (95% Conf: L x W = 6.90 – 7.21 × 5.71 – 5.95 μm; Q = 1.19 – 1.23); Pleurocystidia common, thin-walled, hyaline, containing yellowish contents in NH4OH/KOH, mostly utriform(ish) to broadly lageniform, ~ 34 – 70 × 12 – 23 (26) μm; Q = 2.4 – 4.4; N = 31; (95% Conf: L x W = 49.9 – 56.7 × 15.9 – 18.4 μm; Q = 3.0 – 3.4); Cheilocystidia abundant, thin-walled, hyaline, without yellowish contents in NH4OH/KOH, mostly broadly clavate (obclavate?) to pyriform though sometimes broadly fusiform, also infrequently resembling pleurocystidia but smaller, ~ (22) 30 – 46 × 10.5 – 18 μm; Q = 2.0 – 3.0; N = 13; (95% Conf: L x W = 33.8 – 40.7 × 13.4 – 16.2 μm; Q = 2.4 – 2.7); Basidia mostly 4-spored, generally somewhat clavate, though a bit more ‘rigid’ (??) with a pinched apex, containing granular contents that are yellowish in NH4OH/KOH, around 22 – 25 × 8.5 – 9.5 μm on average; Subhymenium cellular, consisting of globose to subglobose to broadly elliptical elements; Lamellar trama inverse and tangled, hyphae with scattered branches and swollen portions, septate, mostly 3 – 6 μm wide; Pileipellis appearing to be a cross between a cutis and collapsed to poorly-constructed trichoderm, elements thin-walled, somewhat gelatinized, hyaline in water, pale brownish in NH4OH/KOH, terminal cells variable, mostly clavate to broadly fusiform and, longer and more cyclindrical inflated elements scattered, narrowly lageniform and subglobose to pyriform terminal cells also scattered along with long, fusiform septate elements, ~ 45 – 90 × 11 – 36 μm; Q = 1.4 – 7.8; N = 14; (95% Conf: L x W = 58.8 – 74.9 × 16.7 – 23.5 μm; Q = 2.9 – 4.6); Stipitipellis a cutis, hyaline and thin-walled, septate, mostly 3.5 – 7 μm thick, though some hyphae infrequently up to 15 μm wide; Caulocystidia common, hyaline and thin-walled, mostly clavate to broadly fusiform, up to about 40 × 17 μm; Clamp Connections not found in any hyphae/tissue.

results.notes: A couple of clusters fruiting in woodchips/mulch at a children’s playground, about noon. Macro: Pileus white with very pale brownish grey scales, remaining somewhat intact near disc and splitting/separating elsewhere, essentially ovate when young, becoming convex with an umbonate center, flocculate/powdery, margin slightly sultcate to striate/lined; Stipe glaborous, white, becoming yellowish when handled/damaged, a thin annulus present; Lamellae white, crowded, free (or nearly so); Odor/Taste odor nondistinctive, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores narrowly ovate to elliptical, hyaline, thick-walled, smooth, dextrinoid with a conspicuous germ pore at apex, ~ 7.0 – 10.5 (11.5) x (5.5 – 5.8) 6.0 – 7.3 (7.5 – 7.6) μm; Q = 1.04 – 1.77; N = 67; (95% Conf: L x W = 8.7 – 9.2 × 6.4 – 6.6 μm; Q = 1.23 – 1.52); Basidia clavate, mostly 4-spored, surrounded by pavement cells, infrequently scattered at lamellar edge, ~ 18 – 24 × 9 – 11 μm; Cheilocystidia abundant, variable, hyaline and collapsing somewhat easy, mostly clavate/rostrate with variable apical excrescences, ~ 28 – 51 x (9)10 – 16 μm; Pleurocystidia abscent, however, there were basida-like elements present with a mucronate or nipple-like apex, sometimes nearly round and others malformed, sometimes as much as four present of which appear to basidia with nearly mature spores attached (see below), not sure what these are as pleurocystidia is typically (if not always) absent from this genus, (they were much longer/thinner than the typical basidia observed, hence why I’m a bit perplexed on what they are); Pileipellis consisting of elongated, septate hyphal elements, mostly cylindrical with rounded ends, though some elements variable in shape and resembling puzzle pieces (???), also some skinnier, pale brown elements scattered, of which were typically much more flexuous; Clamp Connections absent.
results.location_name: Panola Mountain State Park, Rockdale Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: Macro: Two scattered basidiomes fruiting from a well decayed pine stump; Pileus about 5 cm broad on the mature specimen and 1.5 cm on the immature fruiting body, whitish with dense greyish fibrils covering the majority of the pileus, more dense at disc, darker when young and fading to a softer/lighter grey in age, margin not line initially, becoming slightly lined upon age/drying; Lamellae crowded, free from stipe, whitish at first becoming a pale creamy yellow in age, edges somewhat frayed or decorated with a faint flocculose-like material; Stipe about 4 to 4.25 mm thick, nearly equal or tapering slightly towards apex of which is slightly flared at attachment to pileus, glabrous, off-white above annulus and more yellowish below, darkening slightly upon handling, though not prominently/conspicuously bruising; Annulus located about at about upper 3/4 of stipe, somewhat membranous, adnate to stipe, concolorous but with a fine layer of grey veil remnant on both top and bottom, of which appearing somewhat appendiculate; Micro: Basidiospores elliptical/ellipsoid (infrequently somewhat limoniform), hyaline, slightly thick-walled, apiculate, monoguttulate (also, some spores with a cell lumina present forming a septum like appearance), germ pore absent or very inconspicuous, ~ (5.8) 6.0 – 7.0 (7.3 – 8.1) x (3.0 – 3.3) 3.5 – 4.0 (4.1 – 4.2) μm; Q = 1.52 – 2.03; N = 68; (95% Conf: L x W = 6.5 – 6.7 × 3.7 – 3.8 μm; Q = 1.73 – 1.79); Basidia mostly 2 to 3-spored, clavate, up around 19 – 22 × 6 – 7 μm (sterigmata up to about 3.5 μm); Pleurocystidia absent; Cheilocystidia present, hyaline, collapsing somewhat easily, mostly cylindrical to narrowly clavate to subcapitate, smooth and thin-walled, flexuous, ~ 34 – 36 × 8 – 13 μm; Q = 2.7 – 5.3; N = 18; (95% Conf: L x W = 38.3 – 41.6 × 8.9 – 10.1 μm; Q = 4.0 – 4.6); Lamellar trama hyaline, thin-walled, irregular to essentially trabecular, containing scattered broadly fusiform to obclavate elements; Pileipellis an intermediate between an interwoven cutis and a collapsing trichoderm, both hyaline and pale brownish-grey (the latter more frequent towards disc)cylindrical hyphal elements, inflated, septate, termini consisting of inflated cylindrical elements with both a rounded and pinched/tapering apex, mostly between 25 – 50 μm in length and 9 – 12 μm in width; Clamp connections not found in any hyphae/tissue.

results.notes: Believe this to be the same species as Obs 370764. Found in same area and same habitat. Macro: Pileus 10 – 20 (25) mm broad, whitish to cream, drying pale yellowish, initially convex and finely pruinose/pubescent, becoming somewhat funnel-shaped and nearly glabrous, margin remaining enrolled throughout, no discoloring noticed when handling; Lamellae subdecurrent, concolorous with pileus/stipe, slightly intervenose, sometimes forked, lamellulae present; Stipe whitish, finely fibrillose/pubescent, subinsititious, basal mycelium white; Odor/Taste odor indistinct to somewhat farinaceous, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores ellipsoid to subamygdaliform, smooth, hyaline, ~ (6.0 – 6.4) 6.5 – 7.5 (7.6 – 8.5) x (3.4 – 3.7) 3.8 – 4.3 (4.4 – 4.5) μm; Q = 1.5 – 2.1; N = 52; (95% Conf: L x W = 6.8 – 7.1 × 3.9 – 4.1 μm; Q = 1.70 – 1.77); Basidia clavate, four-spored, ~ 26 – 38 × 6 – 8 μm; Cystidia present on gill face/edge, essentially indifferent (cystidia on lamellar edge somewhat thinner/shorter), cylindrical to narrowly clavate, mostly thin-walled, hyaline, sometimes refractive in NH4OH, ~ 45 – 75 × 7 – 9 μm; Pileipellis a cutis consisting of hyaline to very pale brown hyphal elements, frequently branched, contorted, diverticulate, termini mostly coralloid-like, irregular, appearing somewhat like small ‘Rameale’-type elements, ~ 2 – 3 (4) μm thick; Pileocystidia rare, subcapitate; Pileal trama interwoven/tangled hyphae, hyaline, mostly thin-walled, up to 10 μm in thickness; Clamp Connections observed and very common in all hyphae/tissue.

results.notes: Collection consisting of a single fruiting body, collected around midday, within mixed woods (mostly oak, hickory, pine and sweetgum). Macro: Pileus ~ 4.5 to 5.5 cm wide, broadly concave, with a slight/broad umbonate center, whitish to off-white covered with very tiny fibrils, somewhat appressed, fibrils ranging from light to darker brown in color, the most dense and dark at disc, thinning out and breaking up towards margin, margin slightly enrolled with scant velar tissue at margin edge, becoming cracked (presumably due to age/weather), thus exposing whitish flesh beneath pileipellis, discoloring yellowish when handled/rubbed; Lamellae free from stipe, very crowded, dark brown with hints of greyish-pink in low light; Stipe about 0.8 to 1.0 cm thick, whitish at apex and off-white to dingy yellow to cream elsewhere, mostly smooth, appearing to be subequal to slightly enlarged towards base (unable to keep stipe intact when attempting to dig up), somewhat stuffed to semi-hollow (possibly in age), context dingy yellow to mustard brown; Annulus/Veil unequal, somewhat elastic, ragged/torn at the edge, mainly concolorous with stipe, dingy brown on the lower surface; Odor/Taste typical phenolic odor, though relatively faint compared to prior collections of species in section Xanthodermatei, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores elliptical, apiculate, pale brown to amber in water, dark brown in KOH, thick-walled, ~ (4.8 – 4.9) 5.0 – 5.6 (5.7 – 6.0) x 3.0 – 3.5 (3.6 – 3.8) μm; Q = 1.37 – 1.76; N = 64; (95% Conf: L x W = 5.20 – 5.36 × 3.25 – 3.34 μm; Q = 1.59 – 1.63); Basidia generally clavate, sometimes inflated-cylindrical, 4-spored, hyaline, ~ 16.0 – 23.0 (27.0) x 6.0 – 7.0 μm; Q = 2.5 – 3.9; N = 14; (Mean L x W = 19.3 × 6.6 μm; Mean Q = 2.9), Sterimata up to 4.5 μm; Pleurocystidia absent; Cheilocystidia somewhat clustered, scattered, common, hyaline, simple and septate, mostly broadly clavate to ovoid-inflated or cylindro-clavate to nearly pyriform (sometimes appearing subglobose from top view), sometimes catenulate in twos, ~ 12.0 – 22.0 (25.0) x (5.7 – 7.3) 8.0 – 12.0 μm; Q = 1.27 – 2.96; N = 32; (95% Conf: L x W = 16.0 – 18.2 × 8.6 – 9.7 μm; Q = 1.8 – 2.1); Pileipellis consisting of cylindrical hyphae, septate, hyaline to pale brownish, mostly between 6 – 10 μm thick, though upwards of 14 μm towards disc; Velar Hyphae not yet observed, descriptions to come; Clamp Connections absent.

A NJMA foray collection. A single specimen brought to the ID table by an unknown foray participant. Found in mixed deciduous woods.

I did smell it, but I cannot recall if the was no odor or if it smelled of chlorine (gravitating toward the latter). The bulb was not collected in its entirety — the radicating root was broken off. Note the delicate fibrillose-cottony partial veil covering the gills of the unexpanded cap.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 20-Feb-23):
I requested this collection to be sampled for LSU instead of ITS. This is because ITS, for some reason, is almost always highly polypmorphic in amanitas from sect. Lepidella sensu Bas, to which this species belongs based on the gross morphology. While LSU can, too, suffer from heterogeneity in lepidellas, it’s typically much better behaved.
The LSU amplicon targeted by Dr. Kudzma is apparently between the LSU0F and LR5 primers. This stretch of the locus is typically 950-960 bps long. However, the LSU0F (forward read) and LR22 (reverse read) primers were used for sequencing. It is not clear why this primer combo was chosen because the LR22 reverse read originates ~370 bps away from the start of the locus and the forward LSU0F read always captures this region well in the absence of heterogeneity. Thus, I would have much preferred a reverse read from LR5 because not only it would normally overlap with the forward read for a few hundred bps, but it would also deliver a much sharper 3’ end of the sequence than the “tired” LSU0F.
Frustratingly, the forward read was found to become heterogeneous at position #474 (from the start of the locus) in a poly-T repeat (Fig. 1). However, unlike the typical 1-base frame shift often seen, this turned out to be a 2-base frame shift! While I’ve seen these a few times before in ITS of boletes and/or amanitas, I never had to deal with them because I would have a reverse read to stitch with a forward one at the point of heterogeneity (the “joined contig” scenario). Here, there was no complementary reverse read to save me, and this is where a read from LR5 would have really helped! Naturally, calling the peaks of a mixture of two haplotypes, one of which is lengthened by the insertion of two bases, is not a fun thing to deal with, especially when one is tasked to screen hundreds of peaks by means of being able to visually recognize and follow a stable and predictable pattern of colored overlapping curves. This was further compounded by the fact that the two haplotypes were a ~1:1 mix, so I couldn’t use peak size/height to my advantage. Reluctantly, I gave the manual resolution of the two haplotypes a try and quickly convinced myself that it was doable. Still, it took me a very long time to finish this job and to be convinced of its quality, but I was able to add almost 470 bases from the point of heterogeneity to the point where the peaks’ shape got too broad for unambiguous interpretation. Reported here is the shorter haplotype. The sequence also has three ambiguous positions visible in the unscrambled part of the LSU0F read; two of these, “Y” and “W”, are located very close to the point of sequence “derailment” (Fig. 1).
A BLASTn-100 of this sequence gave two accessions of a nameless amanita from China, MW016757 & MW016758, as top hits at 98.6-98.7% similarity. Sequence alignment showed that MO376018 and the Asian taxon have 7 hard mismatches and 4 soft mismatches (gaps & ambiguities). I checked these positions, most of which occur in the scrambled region, and confirmed them to be real, i.e., no mistakes made in my base assignments. The two GenBank accessions reference an unpublished work titled “Amanita tangconc and Amanita baltaradicata, two new species of Amanita section Roanokenses from China”. An online search of either name came back empty-handed; however, a search of the first accession No. led to a 2021 publication titled “Two new species of Amanita section Roanokenses with a radicating basal bulb”.1. Therein, the two accessions are associated with Amanita alboradicata — one of the two reported taxa. The free copy of the paper doesn’t show any pictures or phylogenetic trees (?), but the written description of A. alboradicata is in good agreement with its North American counterpart, which I dubbed Amanita amerialboradicata.
In the “one-click” ML tree I built in Phylogeny.fr from BLASTn-100 hits of my sequence (Fig. 2), MO376018 is a sister taxon of the Asian A. alboradicata, and these two in turn cluster next to 3 accessions called A. castanopsidis (same as A. castanopsis, a misspelling?). These three species form a highly supported clade within sect. Roanokenses in the ML-tree, and this relationship is verbally confirmed in the paper.
Compare A. amerialboradicata with RET’s Amanita magniradix nom. prov. that is possibly represented by the sequenced obs 282271. The LSU sequence of that species is very different.
Reference:
1 https://www.researchgate.net/...

DNA Results & Discussion:
A joint contiguous full-length ITS sequence of 650 bps has been obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The forward read becomes heteromorphic at character #72, and even though the two haplotypes can be resolved manually, the clean reverse read provides the rest of the sequence. The reverse read also becomes heteromorphic at exactly the same point, but approaching it from the other direction, naturally. The two reads are thus joined at character #71, a “T”, for a full-length contig.
Surprisingly, the derived nrITS sequence is a 99-100% match to several GenBank accessions of T. rubrobrunneus, including Steve Russell’s MK560151 (https://mycomap.com/6288) and Sigrid Jakob’s MN498106 (https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/31878542), the latter collected in Arizona (!). Also surprisingly, there are several misidentifications as T. felleus, which don’t makes sense, as the two taxa are so very different morphologically; the concept of T. felleus, the type species for the genus, is well-established on either side of the Atlantic.
There are few ITS accessions labeled as Tylopilus in GenBank and their coverage of species is very poor. There are no ITS accessions labeled as Tylopilus intermedius, but a single purported intermedius voucher was sampled for 3 other loci: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/....
A GB-rendered phylo tree has been uploaded to this observation.

results.notes:
(NOTE: These observations occurred throughout July.)
One photo shows three objects that I think are truffles. Each shows signs of chewing which exposes an interior with a black powder that appears to be spores (see 40x microscope photo).
Several times something like these objects have appeared near our house. These include one being carried by an Eastern Chipmunk, the three objects shown in the photo, and black powder deposits near a perch frequented by chipmunks.

Specimens: largest of the three is ~28 mm across; no gills, no stalk, no obvious attachment.
Surface: Smooth, dark-brown, very hard shelled.
Spores: Very black; spherical with a diameter of ~30 microns.
Habitat: Mixed woods including Eastern Hemlock and White Pine as well as many hardwood species.

results.notes: Yellow Stainer. Common and found in Eucalypt forests, Pastures and now becoming more common in Urban areas. Poisonous causing gastric upsets to some people and should be avoided. The stem stains yellow when broken and has a phenol like odour. Easily confused with the Edible Horse Mushroom (A arvensis). There is apparently a very similar species that is included in the Xanthodermus group that grows with exotic trees that may be introduced further confusing the issue. Cap to 100mm white with brownish stains and rather a square shape when young. Gills Pink turning brown with ripening spore.
